title: Theme image build-time optimization script
description: Create npm script to optimize all theme images at build time using Sharp. ## What this does Runs before theme packaging/deploy. Generates optimized versions of all theme images. ## Output structure ``` assets/images/ ├── hero.jpg # Original (keep for source) ├── hero.webp # Optimized full-size ├── hero-1920.webp # Responsive sizes ├── hero-1280.webp ├── hero-640.webp └── projects/ ├── project1.jpg ├── project1.webp ├── project1-800.webp └── project1-400.webp ``` ## Script requirements - Use Sharp (npm package) - Generate webp versions of all jpg/png - Generate responsive sizes: 640, 800, 1280, 1920 (configurable) - Quality: 82 for photos, 90 for graphics (configurable) - Skip if optimized version newer than source - Report savings (before/after sizes) ## Configuration ```javascript // optimize.config.js module.exports = { contexts: { hero: { sizes: [640, 1280, 1920, 2560], quality: 85 }, cards: { sizes: [400, 800], quality: 80 }, thumbnails: { sizes: [200, 400], quality: 75 } } }; ``` ## package.json scripts ```json { "scripts": { "images:optimize": "node scripts/optimize-images.js", "images:watch": "nodemon --watch assets/images -e jpg,png --exec npm run images:optimize", "prebuild": "npm run images:optimize", "package": "npm run images:optimize && zip -r theme.zip themes/chris-theme" } } ``` ## Developer workflow documentation Include in README or CONTRIBUTING: 1. Add source images (jpg/png) to assets/images/ 2. Run npm run images:optimize (or let prebuild do it) 3. Reference optimized versions in templates: ```handlebars ``` 4. Commit both source AND optimized images ## Acceptance - [ ] Script processes all images in assets/images/ - [ ] Generates webp versions - [ ] Generates responsive sizes per config - [ ] Skips unchanged files (incremental) - [ ] Reports size savings - [ ] npm run images:optimize works - [ ] Developer workflow documented

title: Research: Analyze motion.zajno.com for motion design patterns
description:
## Goal
Analyze https://motion.zajno.com/ to understand their motion design approach and determine what we can replicate.

## Key Questions
- How do the project components load/animate?
- What techniques are used (CSS animations, GSAP, WebGL, or simpler approaches)?
- Is full WebGL actually needed, or can we achieve similar effects with CSS/JS?
- Can we add 3D effects to project cards without heavy WebGL?

## Performance Analysis
- [ ] Check frame rate during animations (target: 60fps+)
- [ ] Check scroll smoothness
- [ ] Test on mobile device
- [ ] Check Core Web Vitals (LCP, FID, CLS)
- [ ] Note any jank or performance issues

## Mobile Analysis
- [ ] Test responsive behavior
- [ ] Check touch interactions
- [ ] Verify accelerometer/gyro effects (if any)
- [ ] Note any mobile-specific degradation

## Deliverables
Catalog of motion design types with one example of each:
- [ ] Page load animations
- [ ] Scroll-triggered animations  
- [ ] Hover/interaction effects
- [ ] Project card animations (with 3D potential)
- [ ] Transitions between sections

## Context
Shifting focus from 'scrollytelling' to broader 'motion design'. Want wow factor without overengineering. Must be smooth and work well on mobile.
close_reason: Research complete. Key finding: motion.zajno.com achieves wow factor WITHOUT WebGL using Lenis (3KB smooth scroll) + GSAP ScrollTrigger + CSS transforms/clip-path. Documented in research/motion-zajno-analysis.md

title: Scene: Content Creator (3D YouTube embed)
description:
## Scene 3: The Content Creator

### Visual
- 3D YouTube embed with perspective effect
- Floating/tilted appearance
- Recent video from channel

### Motion Design (from research)
**Primary principles:** Zoom, Masking
**Secondary:** Dimension
**Animation tier:** A-tier (CSS 3D transforms)

### Animation Spec
1. **Entry animation:**
   - Scale from 0.8 → 1.0
   - Rotate from rotateY(-15deg) → rotateY(-5deg)
   - Duration: 0.8s cubic-bezier

2. **Resting state:**
   ```css
   transform: perspective(1000px) rotateY(-5deg) rotateX(2deg);
   box-shadow: 20px 20px 60px rgba(0,0,0,0.3);
   ```

3. **Hover:**
   - Flatten: rotateY(0deg) rotateX(0deg)
   - Lift: translateZ(20px)
   - Shadow softens

4. **Click/focus:**
   - Zoom to fill more viewport
   - Video plays

### Technical Implementation
- Use lite-youtube-embed for performance
- Intersection Observer for lazy load
- CSS 3D transforms (NO WebGL needed)

### Assets Required
- [ ] YouTube channel ID / recent video ID
- [ ] Custom thumbnail fallback

### Mobile
- Reduce 3D tilt effect
- Touch to play
- Smaller shadow
close_reason: Content Creator scene fully implemented: 3D YouTube embed with perspective transforms, entry animation, hover effects, mobile responsive, and reduced motion support. Tests pass.

title: Migrate existing Ghost images to optimized format
Asset: Windswept sand dune video at page bottom
description:
# Windswept + Captured Scroll Footer Showcase

Cinematic footer section showcasing blog scroll capture with ambient windswept background.

## Visual Concept
- **Foreground**: Captured scroll video (blog posts scrolling) - full bleed
- **Background**: Windswept sand dune video - visible through blend/transparency
- **Effect**: Creates atmospheric, premium showcase of content

## Compression Requirements (CRITICAL)
Both videos must be ultra-compressed while maintaining high quality:

### Target Specs:
| Metric | Target |
|--------|--------|
| File size | < 2MB per video (total < 4MB) |
| Quality | CRF 28-30 (vs current CRF 18) |
| Resolution | 1920x1080 (desktop), scaled for mobile |
| Format | H.264 + WebM fallback (VP9) |
| Bitrate | ~1-2 Mbps max |

### Encoding Command (optimized):
```bash
# Two-pass H.264 for optimal compression
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -c:v libx264 -preset veryslow -crf 28 \
  -vf "scale=1920:-2" -pix_fmt yuv420p \
  -movflags +faststart output.mp4

# WebM fallback (better compression)
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -crf 32 -b:v 0 \
  -vf "scale=1920:-2" output.webm
```

## Implementation

### HTML Structure:
```html
<section class="blog-showcase-footer">
  <video class="windswept-bg" autoplay muted loop playsinline>
    <source src="windswept.webm" type="video/webm">
    <source src="windswept.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  </video>
  <video class="scroll-capture" autoplay muted loop playsinline>
    <source src="scroll-capture.webm" type="video/webm">
    <source src="scroll-capture.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  </video>
</section>
```

### CSS Blend Effect:
```css
.blog-showcase-footer {
  position: relative;
  height: 100vh;
  overflow: hidden;
}
.windswept-bg {
  position: absolute;
  inset: 0;
  object-fit: cover;
  z-index: 1;
}
.scroll-capture {
  position: absolute;
  inset: 0;
  object-fit: cover;
  z-index: 2;
  mix-blend-mode: overlay; /* or screen, multiply */
  opacity: 0.85;
}
```

### Technical Requirements:
- [x] Lazy load (below fold)
- [x] Autoplay, muted, loop, playsinline
- [x] playbackRate = 0.5 for windswept (ultra slow-mo)
- [x] GPU-accelerated (will-change: transform)
- [x] Pause when not visible (IntersectionObserver)
- [x] Reduced motion: show static poster instead

## Acceptance
- [ ] Windswept video < 2MB, plays smoothly
- [ ] Captured scroll video < 2MB, shows blog posts
- [ ] Blend effect creates cohesive visual
- [ ] Total assets < 4MB
- [ ] Properly lazy loaded
- [ ] Pauses when off-screen
- [ ] Reduced motion fallback works

title: Ghost CMS media auto-optimization
description: # Automatic Media Optimization for Ghost Uploads Lazy image optimization with Cloudflare free tier caching. ## Architecture ``` Request → Cloudflare (cache miss) → Optimizer → Origin image ↓ Cloudflare caches result ↓ Next request → Cloudflare edge (cache hit, fast) ``` First request generates optimized version, all subsequent requests served from Cloudflare edge cache. ## Existing Infrastructure - **Cloudflare CDN** (free tier) ✓ - Cache stores optimized images after first generation ## Responsive Sizing Strategy Images need multiple sizes per **usage context**: | Context | Widths | Formats | |---------|--------|---------| | Hero/full-bleed | 2560, 1920, 1280, 640 | webp + jpg fallback | | Card/thumbnail | 800, 400 | webp + jpg fallback | | Inline content | 1200, 600 | webp + jpg fallback | ## Recommended: imgproxy Lightweight Go service for on-demand image optimization. ### URL structure: ``` # Original /content/images/photo.jpg # Optimized (via imgproxy) /img/w:800/f:webp/plain/content/images/photo.jpg ``` ### Theme srcset example: ```html ``` ### Deployment: - Run imgproxy as Docker container alongside Ghost - Nginx/Caddy routes `/img/*` to imgproxy - Cloudflare caches all `/img/*` responses ### Cache headers: ``` Cache-Control: public, max-age=31536000, immutable ``` ## Alternative: Sharp middleware Node.js middleware using Sharp library: - Integrate directly with Ghost/Express - Same URL-based transform pattern - No separate service to manage ## Trade-offs | Approach | Pros | Cons | |----------|------|------| | imgproxy | Battle-tested, fast, feature-rich | Extra service to run | | Sharp middleware | Single codebase | More custom code | | On-upload generation | No request-time cost | Storage bloat, inflexible | ## First-visit latency - Theme change = cache miss for new sizes - First few visitors experience generation delay (~100-500ms) - Mitigation: warm cache by crawling site after deploy ## Acceptance - [ ] imgproxy (or equivalent) deployed - [ ] Theme uses optimized URLs with srcset - [ ] Cloudflare caching verified (check headers) - [ ] Long TTL (1 year) for immutable images - [ ] webp served to supporting browsers - [ ] jpg fallback for older browsers - [ ] Cache warming script for deploys

title: Foundation: Lenis + GSAP ScrollTrigger setup
description:
## Animation Foundation

### Core Setup
Install and configure the animation stack:

```bash
npm install lenis gsap
```

```javascript
// lib/scroll.ts
import Lenis from "lenis"
import { gsap } from "gsap"
import { ScrollTrigger } from "gsap/ScrollTrigger"

gsap.registerPlugin(ScrollTrigger)

export const initScroll = () => {
  const lenis = new Lenis()
  lenis.on("scroll", ScrollTrigger.update)
  gsap.ticker.add((time) => lenis.raf(time * 1000))
  gsap.ticker.lagSmoothing(0)
  return lenis
}
```

### Deliverables
- [ ] Lenis smooth scroll working
- [ ] GSAP ScrollTrigger integrated
- [ ] Base page scroll behavior smooth
- [ ] prefers-reduced-motion detection

### Dependencies
- Requires: Design System (for CSS variables)

### Performance Target
- 60fps minimum scroll
- No jank on scene transitions

title: Motion: Hero depth map parallax effect
description:
Apply depth map-based parallax to hero desert image using PixiJS DisplacementFilter.

## Assets
- Original: `desert_dune_tufts_big_red.jpg`
- Depth map: `desert_dune_tufts_big_red_depth_anything_2_greyscale.png`

## Implementation
- Use PixiJS DisplacementFilter with grayscale depth map
- White pixels (foreground plants/sand) move MORE on parallax
- Black pixels (sky/distant dunes) move LESS
- Tie displacement to mouse position (desktop) and/or gyroscope (mobile)

## Reference
- Lando Norris website uses similar technique
- Depth Anything V2 generated the depth map

## Technical approach
```javascript
const displacementFilter = new PIXI.filters.DisplacementFilter(depthMapSprite);
image.filters = [displacementFilter];
// On mousemove, adjust displacementFilter.scale.x/y
```

## Acceptance
- [ ] Parallax effect responds to mouse movement
- [ ] Foreground elements (plants) move more than background
- [ ] Effect is subtle and enhances depth, not distracting
- [ ] Works with reduced-motion: disabled or very subtle
- [ ] Mobile: consider gyroscope or disable gracefully
close_reason: Implemented with optical flow motion tracking: 32x32 camera feed, One-Euro filter, separate mobile/desktop configs. Replaced heavy TensorFlow face detection.

comments.author: Chris Dilger
comments.text:
Fixed gyroscope sensitivity issues:

1. **Baseline calibration** - Now captures initial phone position as 'center' instead of assuming 45° beta offset. However the user holds their phone becomes neutral.

2. **Responsive tilt range** - Changed from ±45° to ±15° for full displacement. Small tilts (15°) now produce noticeable parallax instead of requiring extreme tilts.

3. **Cleaner architecture** - Refactored input method chain: Face Tracking → Gyroscope (iOS) → Mouse/Touch. Removed the motion button UI for cleaner UX.

4. **iOS permission flow** - First touch automatically triggers permission request, no explicit button needed.

All 11 tests passing. Desktop parallax verified working via Chrome automation.

title: Embed Components: X.com, GitHub, YouTube
description:
## Rich Embed Components ✅ DECISIONS RESOLVED

### YouTube Embed
**Decision:** lite-youtube-embed + CSS 3D transforms

```html
<lite-youtube videoid="VIDEO_ID" style="background-image: url(thumb.webp);">
</lite-youtube>
```

```css
.youtube-3d {
  transform: perspective(1000px) rotateY(-5deg) rotateX(2deg);
  transition: transform 0.4s ease;
}
.youtube-3d:hover {
  transform: perspective(1000px) rotateY(0) rotateX(0);
}
```

- Lazy loads YouTube iframe on click
- ~1KB vs official iframe (~500KB)
- CSS 3D sufficient (no WebGL needed)

### X.com / Twitter Embed
**Decision:** Static preview image + link

- Official embeds slow (hurt LCP)
- Generate preview image via screenshot or API
- Link to actual tweet/thread
- Matches design system typography

### GitHub Embed
**Decision:** Custom renderer

- API: `https://api.github.com/repos/{owner}/{repo}`
- Display: name, description, stars, forks, language
- Syntax highlighting: Shiki or Prism
- Code blocks: custom styled `<pre>` with copy button

### Implementation Priority
1. YouTube (lite-youtube-embed)
2. GitHub (custom renderer)
3. X.com (static preview)

### Assets Required
- [ ] lite-youtube-embed package
- [ ] GitHub API integration code
- [ ] X.com preview screenshot workflow

### Performance

- "Software Engineer" subtitle

### Motion Design (from research)
**Primary principles:** Parallax, Masking, Easing
**Secondary:** Fade, Dimension

### Animation Spec
1. **Page load sequence** (stagger 0.1s apart):
   - Background layers fade in
   - Title text: `cubic-bezier(0.4, 0, 0.2, 1)` + translateY(-20px)
   - Subtitle: fade + translateY
   - Scroll indicator: pulse animation

2. **Parallax layers:**
   - Sky: static or slow CSS gradient shift
   - Mountains: `yPercent: -20` on scroll
   - Mid dunes: `yPercent: -35` on scroll
   - Foreground: `yPercent: -50` on scroll

3. **Scroll reveal:** Hero content clips out via `clip-path: inset()` as user scrolls

### Assets Required
- [ ] desert-sky.webp (or CSS gradient)
- [ ] desert-mountains.png (transparent, ~1920x600)
- [ ] desert-dunes-mid.png (transparent, ~1920x400)
- [ ] desert-foreground.png (transparent, ~1920x300)

### Performance
- 120fps target
- CSS transforms only (GPU accelerated)
- Lazy load below-fold layers

### Mobile
- Reduce parallax intensity (50% of desktop)
- Touch-friendly scroll
- `prefers-reduced-motion`: static fallback
